Peter-

There is a Namban tsuba book out there. Paperback. We
requested Bob Orssman look for it, but he could not
find it. It is supposedly a $25 book, and not very
old.
   Jim G. purchased it from a book dealer. In it there
are some outstanding rapier style examples, including
near matching western pieces upon which they may have
been based.

I do not recall much in the way of cupped guards. 
  Could you please give your opinion against the
cupped guards being not attributed to westerd style?
I've heard 2 arguments against it, but not in much
depth.

As i mentioned, many of the tsuba 'cup' the wrong way.
The one I recently picked up is more of a bowl shape
(more of an L edge to it, but about 1 cm deep), and
would have been worn correctly cupped towards the
hand.

Curran



--- Peter A Bleed <pbleed1@...> wrote:
> 
> Friends,
> I have become rather interested in Namban tsuba that
> are made to look like
> rapier guards. They are pretty rare and I own only a
> couple and have seen
> only a few others. In that regard, I have liked
> looking at other Namban
> tsuba and cupped guards. All that to say this is an
> interesting thread.
> John, I'd love to see your rapier style guard if you
> can post a pic.
> Let me say, however,  that I am not certain about
> the link between cupped
> tsuba and European swords. I have seen a number of
> cupped tsuba that I
> suppose could be inspired by European cuphilts, but
> may of these look like
> they are Hizen style rather than "Namban" (whatever
> that is). Furthermore,
> in the case of the tsuba that got this conversation
> started, it looks to me
> like the cup would have pointed TOWARD the blade!
> Pretty different from the
> European cuphilt style.
